text: There is racism everywhere. it is often due to homophobia and miseducation or a lack of education. We all must do better! No one deserves to be discriminated!

answers.text: @noisesg thanks for clarifying. Was confused for a second as to how homophobia is a common reason for racism. Xenophobia makes a lot more sense.
@cigarxttesaftersex I should have probably replaced homophobia with xenophobia. my bad - pretty embarrassing ☺️

@noisesg I can understand what you have just said. But you still have not explained what you mean in your initial comment where you pin pointed homophobia as a common reason for racism. How does being homophobic suddenly equal being racist? Those are two separate labels with separate meanings and connotations.

@cigarxttesaftersex I can bet with you that there are many people that hate others without even knowing why. People are afraid of people of different colour or culture or religion or gender they don’t know and many express this with disgust/hate/discrimination because of their own insecurities and lack of education.

@noisesg you said “there is racism everywhere” then followed that up with saying “it is often due to homophobia...”. How is racism due to homophobia? I don’t see how it’s mutually inclusive, that if one is homophobic, then one MUST by that logic also be racist.
@no_name_42069 Did I say that? Please elaborate.
@noisesg I support equal rights for everyone, but how is not liking gay people linked to saying the n word

text: not sure how unpopular my take on this may be but i dont really think the murder had anything to be with racism, at least so far

answers.text: @183828382_aaa even if you do not think that mate, this incident brought racism to light. huge topic, touchy, but very relevant in today’s society. if no change is done now, the future generations will have it worse.
@183828382_aaa r u dumb

@183828382_aaa if you’d like more evidence, feel free to dm me. 
To further answer your question on the unequal rights of black people, here are a few excerpts: • Centre for American Progress: The United States is a contradiction. Its founding principles embrace the ideals of freedom and equality, but it is a nation built on the systematic exclusion and suppression of communities of color. From the start, so many of this country’s laws and public policies, which should serve as the scaffolding that guides progress, were instead designed explicitly to prevent people of color from fully participating. • Voting and citizenship were largely denied to people of color until 1870 • Lawmakers continued to exclude and suppress Americans of color even after the 14th and 15th amendments • After Reconstruction, white nationalists waged a campaign of terror to suppress Black voters and seize control of Southern state legislatures • The systematic exclusion and suppression of voters of color during this period was not limited to Southern states • The U.S. Supreme Court gave states the green light to suppress voters of color • Millions of Americans of color remain structurally excluded from American democracy

@183828382_aaa Stop and frisk data, for example, consistently show that about 3 percent of these encounters produce any evidence of a crime. So 97 percent-plus of these people are getting punished solely because they belong to a group that statistically commits some crimes at a higher rate, in Suspect Citizens written by Kelsey Shoub. “Blacks are almost twice as likely to be pulled over as whites — even though whites drive more on average,” “blacks are more likely to be searched following a stop,” and “just by getting in a car, a black driver has about twice the odds of being pulled over, and about four times the odds of being searched.” • 2013 Justice Department Study: Black and Latino drivers are more likely to be searched once they have been pulled over. About 2 percent of white motorists were searched, vs. 6 percent of black drivers and 7 percent of Latinos.

@183828382_aaa 
Here you go, the list of evidences: • On the Mythologized ideology of Black Criminality: Paul Gilroy (1979) argues that black criminality is a myth perpetuated by racist stereotypes. Ethnic minorities are over-criminalised and over-represented in statistics due to the criminal justice system acting on these racial stereotypes. - 
According to Phillips and Bowling (2012), the oppressive policing and the practise of stop-and-search allows police to arrest individuals of interests with no reasonable suspicion, causing ethnic minority to be “overpoliced” as well as “under-protected”. - 
The MacPherson Report (1999) has also exemplified how prevalent police racism can be, as the inquiry into the wrongful murder of Stephen Lawrence concluded that there was institutional racism and corruption in the Metropolitan Police with officers holding deeply ingrained racist attitudes. His death was held to be marred by a combination of “professional incompetence, institutional racism, and a failure of leadership by senior officers”. Sociologist Holdoway also shows how negative stereotypes are repeatedly endorsed through the police Canteen Culture, where police create racist banter to cement solidarity. • Phillips and Bowling (2012) found that the CPS was more likely to drop cases against ethnic minorities due to weaker evidence presented to them by the police and based on the stereotyping of ethnic minorities as “criminals”. - Similarly, Hudson and Bramhall (2015) argue that pre-sentence reports for ethnic minorities were harshly written by probation officers and allow for unwitting discrimination. • According to the ministry of justice, members of the black community are 7 times more likely to be stopped and searched, 3 and a half times more likely to be arrested and 5 times more likely to be imprisoned. • victim surveys have also found black people to be overwhelmingly overrepresented among those identified by victims as offenders

@hillarykylie " We find no evidence
of anti-Black or anti-Hispanic disparities across
shootings, and White officers are not more likely to
shoot minority civilians than non-White officers.
Instead, race-specific crime strongly predicts
civilian race. This suggests that increasing diversity
among officers by itself is unlikely to reduce
racial disparity in police shootings." That was the

no, police arent just targeting a particular race.

to believe that the police force to oppressive and racist?

To call me a racist is just honestly fucking stupid. I DO NOT AGREE WITH THE ACTIONS OF THE COPS. The cops committed murder and i acknowledge that. I think they derserve to be jailed and charged with murder, no doubt about that. How is that racist? Cite me the evidence where i show that one race is superior than the other.

Regrding the rights of the blacks being stripped from them, what rights are being removed? I need evidence if you wish to convince me. Regarding the the justification of the outcry, i may have phrased it a bit off so ill state my opinion o

@183828382_aaa Dude what are you talking about? the outcry is completely justified because BLACK PEOPLE HAVE BEEN OPPRESSED AND MALIGNED SINCE CIVILIZATION. 
Their voices have been stifled and suppressed for years, and rioting is the only channel where their voices may be finally heard and where change will be solidified. People are furious, aggravated and frustrated by years of having their rights stripped away, and having to bear the brunt of white supremacy. 
The phrase “pattern where he kills black people”, followed by your indignant denial that “it doesn’t mean he is racist” is sufficient to show how much of an imbecile you are. 
Police in the US have had an extensive history of racial profiling of POCs and falsely incriminating and arresting the black community. 
A life of an innocent black man is lost, along with the thousands of others whose lives have been destroyed and annihilated due to white supremacy, a prejudiced judicial system, and racist and discriminatory practices upheld by cops. 
Racism is undoubtedly a paramount aspect to the murder of George Floyd - your failure to acknowledge and recognise this is embarrassing and humiliating. 
Do your research on the cop before talking. 
You sound extremely uneducated on how racism works and the magnitude and severity of police brutality. 
This is coming from a Sociology undergrad who’s studied broadly on the issue of Racism and White Supremacy.
@antimantha omg exactly. The fucking police officer is a self proclaimed white supremacist and fascist. What more do we expect from an individual like that.

@183828382_aaa I’m sorry but your statement is incredibly problematic and flawed. Police brutality in the US has always been targeted towards the black community, and America has perennially sustained itself through a regime built on White Supremacy and Black Oppression. 
Racist policing is extremely rampant and prevalent with the police, due to myths of black criminality and harmful stereotypes pinned against the black community which eventually predisposed them to a higher likelihood of being incriminated and murdered than their White counterparts. 
To argue that the incident does not reek of racism speaks volumes of your IGNORANCE and imbecility. 
George Floyd died a wrongful death. He did not and never resisted against the authority, yet he was brutally assassinated. 
And for the record, yes your opinion is extremely uneducated and unpopular - and also racist. 
It shocks me that people like you fail to recognise how racism is weaved into our Everyday lives. 
You don’t get to dictate what is “racism” to you when you’re not part of the demographic that has been hit. 
Educate yourself before spouting uncorroborated facts.

My point with the Amy Cooper incident is that the police wouldnt blindly side with anyone. The only one that was being racist and that i dont support is Amy Cooper. Would the police focus their investigations more on Christian? We wouldnt know, there is not enough evidence to suggest that. Would the cops have shot Christian? Possibly, but it would turn out to be unjustified. Therefore, i still do not believe the cops are racist here, but rather is just Amy Cooper trying her luck to trick the police to help her case, which ultimately failed.

@_28brandon for the Wayne Reyes incident, he had a shotgun before he was shot, even the jury at that time deemed that it was justified. As for the latrell toles one, he went for the officers handgun. Am i saying he is not racist? No of course not, but again, im saying that we dont know whether he is racist and the actions against george floyd had racist intent. Even if he was racist, i doesnt automatically mean that the entire police force is racist. My point that im trying to get across is that currently, we do not have enough evidence to show that the killing of George Floyd had something to do with racism just because its a white cop and a black suspect. I hope we can at least reach the consensus that until investigations are finished, we shouldnt just assume this was a racial issue

@183828382_aaa I agree with u that America is not a racist place whereby many people don't condone racism. However, this incident in the larger context of police brutality that Black Americans have faced, shows how the judicial system tolerate and grants some racist police officers the power to inflict injustice on Black Americans (with little repurcussions). This case of Floyd blew up because he died. However, there are many instances where Black Americans have been threatened at gun point for trivial misunderstanding, or been treated unfairly or arrested by the police for doing everyday things that others are doing as well. Perhaps you can do more research on other cases of Black Americans facing injustice from the police, and put this incident in the bigger context of things. My point is, the judicial system in America has perpetuated racism amongst police officers that are racist. Eg. On the case of Amy Cooper, she knew that she could call the police on a Black person and falsely accuse him because she knows that the police are more likely to side with her and focus their investigation more on Christian Cooper than on the reliability of her claims. Which could cause Christian Cooper to be arrested without reason, have his integrity as a person questioned and lose his dignity in some way. She knew she could use the police as a weapon and why? Because the police have established themselves as an unfair law enforcement that will side with the White than POCs because of who? Racist police officers.
